pkg/trace/{api,writer}: add buffered channels to blocking goroutines (#3375) This change changes the writer's input channel and the payload sender's
input channels to buffered ones to avoid blocking in goroutines. This is
a much better approach because it is what buffered channels were built
for and avoids pressure on the runtime scheduler.

Ref: https://github.com/golang/go/wiki/Performance#blocking-profiler

[macOS/apm] Do not disable APM when the old conf option is not set (#3304) Likely because of an oversight, the `apm` check that runs trace-agent
on macOS was still checking that the old `apm_enabled` option was set
to `true` before starting trace-agent. This logic would also make
trace-agent not start by default on macOS.

Since at least 6.0.0, trace-agent should be enabled/disabled with the
`apm_config.enabled` setting (or the `DD_APM_ENABLED` env var). This
change also makes the trace-agent start by default on macOS.

pkg/trace/agent: parallelize processor (#3374) This change parallelizes the processor when a feature flag is set. To set the feature flag, an environment variable needs to be set, e.g.
```
DD_APM_FEATURES=parallel_process
```
Change log entry is eluded while this is hidden under feature flag.

Follows from: https://github.com/DataDog/datadog-agent/pull/3354
Other reference: https://github.com/DataDog/datadog-agent/pull/3183

follow up to a comment from #3364

pkg/trace/api: add back lost profiling endpoints (#3365) Switching to a custom mux implementation caused us to lose pprof
endpoints. This change adds them back.

pkg/trace/writer: switch from flushing based on spans to size (#3364) * pkg/trace/writer: switch from flushing based on spans to size

This change modifies the flushing logic to flush based on an estimated
payload size as opposed to a maximum number of spans.

Adding the payload size computation slightly decreases the
trace-handling method's speed, but is negligible considering that the
only thing this function is doing is technically two `append` calls.

```
benchmark                         old ns/op     new ns/op     delta
BenchmarkHandleSampledTrace-4     1117          1373          +22.92%
```
Fix getShortImageName on old docker version (#3367)

Avoid deadlock when go switch thread Locking the GIL in the setup could end up in a python deadlock. As go
might switch threads python will end up with a GIL locked but in a
different thread. This would cause 'PyRun_SimpleString' to block
indefinitely.

We now lock the OS thread and acquire the GIL just when we need it (like
we do in the agent).

pkg/trace/api: never drop traces (#3239) This change modifies the HTTP receiver to never drop traces. Dropping
traces does not bring any real benefit. If a user wishes to process a
high amount of traces, he should be able to do so at the cost of
hardware resources. For now, we are safeguarded against excessive use of
memory and cpu by the watchdog system.

pkg/trace/config: turn log throttling on by default (#3309) This change makes sure that the (informerly deprecated) option
`apm_config.log_throttling` is turned on by default. This means that
error logs are rate limited to a maximum of 10 every 10 seconds
(hardcoded).

Having this always off resulted in countless spammy logs and support
cases. It is useless to address more than 10 error messages at a time,
which are most of the cases the same one.

For those rare cases, a change has been made where log throttling is
automatically disabled when logging level is set to "debug" and log
throttling is not specifically set by the user in the config.

[config] Remove doc entries on unused JMXFetch settings (#3269) `jmx_pipe_name` and `jmx_pipe_path` are options that are not used by
the Agent/JMXFetch anymore (they date back to when the Agent 6 was
communicating with JMXFetch through a unix socket, which isn't the case
anymore). Remove them from docs/tests.

Avoid loading stuff into memory to generate a flare (#3197) * Use Copy instead of ReadAll + Write

So we don't load the stacktrace into memory

* Use a pipe instead of a bytes buffer

So we don't load the entire flare zip file into memory before sending it

* The writter iface should return the bytes it processed, not written

This made a io.Copy into a RedactingWriter fail with ErrShortWrite ("write
accepted fewer bytes than requested").

Eg: io.Discard.Write returns len(buf) even though it really writes 0 bytes.

* Increase time we keep the connection open

Since we don't ReadAll now, but we read as we go, plus the RedactingWriter
needs to process the file as it's read, 500ms was barely enough to read
2MB on my system (with heap profiling enabled).

[macOS omnibus][kerberos] Rely on the system libraries (#3261) On macOS, the python `pykerberos` package expects to be linked against
the shared Kerberos lib provided by the base system, rather than our
own compiled `libkrb5`. (otherwise, at runtime, importing pykerberos
fails with all kinds of failed symbol lookups)

So let's just rely on the system-provided lib. Note that the "catch-all" whitelist
statement on `embedded/lib/python2.7` covers us here (even though it's way
too broad, I'll fix that in a separate PR).

Not 100% confident how backward compatibility would work if we were to
upgrade our mac builder to a later macOS version though.

pkg/trace/api: avoid deadlock (#3224) This change avoids a deadlock when exiting prematurely due to an error
in the stream msgpack decoder. Previously the channel was not closed
when returning early.

pkg/trace/agent: add stream decoder (#3214) This change adds a stream decoder which decodes traces and sends them for processing one at a time, instead of decoding everything and then iterating through everything once more to process.

[Logs]: Allow for directory tagging when tailing files (#3211)

Fix host alias for GCE instances with custom hostname (#3137) Currently, datadog agent derives the GCE instance name from the hostname that is fetched from metadata endpoint `/instance/hostname`. For GCE instances with custom hostnames, this approach can result in wrong instance names being derived, because the instance name may not even be part of the custom hostname.

In fact, the GCE instance name can be directly retrieved from metadata endpoint `/instance/name`.

No longer decrypt secret in commands when it's not needed Secrets are no longer decrypted in agent command when it's not needed

number the number of times the 'secret_command_backend' executable will be
called.

pkg/trace/api: ensure media-type gets extracted correctly (#3203) This change ensures that media type gets parsed correctly in the

value "application/json;charset=utf-8" would fail to be parsed
correctly.

[codecov] Remove PR comments and github status of project coverage (#3191) We've determined the only information that's useful to have on Github
from codecov is the github status on the patch coverage:

* PR comments are intrusive and provide info that's often wrong
* project coverage isn't accurate enough to be useful for most PRs

Coverage is still uploaded to codecov, so all the info is still
available on codecov.io.

This also works on python2, although it's slighlt less performant since it

[omnibus] Remove protobuf-py from omnibus deps of Agent (#3160) protobuf-py is needed by integrations-core. On Linux, we want
to ship protobuf-py with the cpp extension for perf reasons, and these
were not available as binary wheels with the `ucs2` build of the python
embedded Agent. This explains why we originally built the protobuf lib
in omnibus.

We now build python with `ucs4`. protobuf-py+cpp binary wheels are
provided for this build. These wheels use the `manylinux1` policy,
which support CentOS 5.
So we're all good relying on these binary wheels instead.

pkg/trace/event: make event service & operation matching insensitive (#3113) * pkg/trace/event: make event service & operation matchin insensitive

This change makes `apm_config.analyzed_rate_by_service` and
`apm_config.analyzed_spans` entries case insensitive. The reasoning
behind this is that Viper always lower-cases keys in the yaml file, make
it impossible to compare against the orginal value. See spf13/viper#411.

pkg/trace/agent: consider UTF-8 characters in tags (#2957) * pkg/trace/agent: consider UTF-8 characters in tags

This change fixes a problem in NormalizeTag where it was assuming
character lengths to be always equal to 1, whereas this isn't always
true for UTF-8 characters.

It also fixes an issue where not all Unicode letters were lower-cased.

There is an edge case to this algorithm where uppercased Unicode characters are not lowercased when their length would end up being different as a result. 24 characters fall into this edge case: https://play.golang.org/p/Af1bIusSbfq

Performance remains virtually unimpacted.

     name                      old time/op    new time/op    delta
     NormalizeTag/ok-4           68.8ns ± 0%    69.2ns ± 0%  +0.58%
     NormalizeTag/trim-4         92.8ns ± 0%    92.5ns ± 0%  -0.32%
     NormalizeTag/trim-both-4     159ns ± 0%     163ns ± 0%  +2.52%
     NormalizeTag/plenty-4        147ns ± 0%     150ns ± 0%  +2.04%
     NormalizeTag/more-4          259ns ± 0%     270ns ± 0%  +4.25%

     name                      old alloc/op   new alloc/op   delta
     NormalizeTag/ok-4            24.0B ± 0%     24.0B ± 0%   0.00%
     NormalizeTag/trim-4          32.0B ± 0%     32.0B ± 0%   0.00%
     NormalizeTag/trim-both-4     64.0B ± 0%     64.0B ± 0%   0.00%
     NormalizeTag/plenty-4        64.0B ± 0%     64.0B ± 0%   0.00%
     NormalizeTag/more-4           128B ± 0%      128B ± 0%   0.00%

     name                      old allocs/op  new allocs/op  delta
     NormalizeTag/ok-4             2.00 ± 0%      2.00 ± 0%   0.00%
     NormalizeTag/trim-4           2.00 ± 0%      2.00 ± 0%   0.00%

Add "Tolerate Unready" Annotation (#2771) * Add "Tolerate Unready" Annotation

This will bypass the normal logic that skips pods that aren't ready.
It's a bit of a divergence from the normal way of doing annotations,
which is that they're based on the container.

This status is global to the pod, though, so I had to come up with
something.
If you were to have a container named `tolerate-unready` this would be
confusing, but still wouldn't collide because it'd still be looking for
things suffixed off that (`.checks` or whatever)

I had a lot of trouble with the testing framework, so I simply adapted
one of the tests I could convince to run on my system to require these
changes by making one of the fixture pods unready, but adding the
annotation so the tests still pass.

[check cmd] Add pause between 2 consecutive runs with `--check-rate` (#2793) * [check cmd] Add pause between 2 consecutive runs with `--check-rate`

`--check-rate` is meant to be used for the metrics that need the
check to run twice before reporting all their metrics. Some of these
checks need some time to pass between their 2 runs, otherwise the runs
are too close in time to provide meaningful samples. This affects the
go cpu check for example.

This sets a pause of 1 seconds between the 2 check runs when
`--check-rate` is used. The option can be set separately with `--pause`
if `--check-times` is used instead (default: no pause).

[flare] add a permissions.log file into the flare archive (#2707) * [flare] implement methods to add permissions info of files added to the flare archive.

Following the format of the permissions.log generated in the Agent 5
except for the mode info which looks like an `ls -l` call:
`-rw-r--r--` instead of `0644` in the old format.

* [flare] creates the permissions.log file in flare while creating the archive.

Only for non-windows system, windows generated flares still won't have
any `permissions.log` file.

* [flare] unit tests for the permissions.log file writing.

* [api] expose the auth token filepath.

* [flare] add auth token permissions infos.

* Add release note entry.

* [flare] fix perms file method signature for windows build.

* [flare] refactor using a state during the archive creation instead of writing each time to the file.

In order to not open the permissions.log file for every lines. I've used
a new struct to store filepaths that will be added to the
`permissions.log` file. Before finally creating the .zip archive, we create
the `permissions.log` file with all files information in one shot.

Slightly change the signature of two methods shared with the DCA:
  - `zipConfigFiles`
  - `zipLogFiles`

This commit doesn't add the `permissions.log` file for the DCA flare archive,
this is why the nil pointer is handled in those methods (to avoid the DCA to be
forced to provide a *PermsInfos instance).

* [flare] fix a bug about reading the copied file instead of the original one.

* [flare] add a missing err test while writing permissions.log header

* [flare] PermsInfos func should not be public.

We don't need them from outside of this pkg.

* [flare] fix permissions check for log files (was using the dst file).

* [flare] changed the PermsInfos composition and made it private.

Bonus, `permsInfo` becomes `filePermsInfo`.

* [flare] archive dca flare generation also create a `permissions.log` file in the archive.

* [flare] wrong func assignement for windows stubbed funcs.

* [flare] while creating dca flare archive, do not fail on permissions.log creation error, just log the error.

[flare] include a status.log with a message if the agent is not running (#2715) * [flare] include a status.log with a message even if the agent is not running.

Previous behavior was no status.log at all, which could be misleading
for the person analysing the flare.

Having the message "agent is not running" in the "faked" `status.log`
avoid the person to be vigilant to the `local` file.

* Add release note entry.

* [flare] cleaner message for missing status.log

* [flare] mention that we can't reach the agent in the config-check.log

* Update the release note entry.

Fix a bug with docker log rotation (#2549) * Fix a bug with docker log rotation

When the option --log-opt max-file=1 and --log-opt max-size were set
the Read() call would become blocking at the log rotation and following
logs would never be tailed.

This commit adds a timeout on the Read() and restarts if the Read()
timeout.

Allow checks config to fail independently of logs config (#2432) ### What does this PR do?

Allows the logs config to be sent if the checks config parsing failed in AD. 
I refactor the `extractTemplatesFromMap` function to return an array of errors. I add the info whether checks or/and logs parsing failed.

I still handle the errors in the `providers` to give context on the errors (did it happen in a pod / docker container / ecs ?)

### Motivation

In Autodiscovery, when the parsing of checks config fails, the logs configs is not parsed and fails. We want to be able to send logs even if the checks config is broken

### Additional Notes

Ideally we would display something in the `agent status` (or `agent configcheck`?) when we fail to parse a config. I'm not sure there is a simple way of doing this for the logs.

[config] Support new 'site' option in Infra Agent (#2412) Overriden by `dd_url` if latter is set. Should be fully backward
compatible.

Windows MSI: allow passing `SITE` option on the command line.

To encourage users not to use 'dd_url' anymore, and to use 'site'
instead, the legacy config importer now ignores dd_url if left to
default.

Also included, not directly required by the feature:
* Improve testability of `config` package:
  * avoid mutating global Datadog config from arbitrary functions  
  * always pass a Config to all these functions
* [flare] Fix domain used to send flares:
  We should use a versioned domain. This was broken since 6.5.0 and
  ec90952dc8f0c6bc68f7c809618c1b0770c1fb65. It didn't prevent
  flares from being sent though.
* [config] Remove unused test fixtures
* [Dockerfiles] Remove explicit setting of DD_DD_URL in entrypoints:
  `dd_url` is an optional setting in Agent 6, no need to always set it
  (and it's actually counter-productive now that we offer the `site`
  option)

Enable add systemd flag to the centos build (#2397) ### What does this PR do?

This PR enables systemd build on the default source build of Centos

### Motivation

We want to enable the journald integration on Centos 7. For this, we need to enable the build flag systemd on Centos


### Note: 

The build succeeded https://gitlab.ddbuild.io/DataDog/datadog-agent/pipelines/715202
And the binary worked on 
- Centos 6
- Centos 7 (with systemd)
- Amazon Linux 
- Amazon Linux 2 (with systemd)

Dont block the agent if we can't send logs (#2373) ### What does this PR do?

Currently if the Senders are not able to consume the messages of the
pipelines (for example, because they can't establish a connection) it
is impossible to stop the logging agent. Even worse, it is impossible
to stop the inputs too because the channels in-between components have
a fixed size.


### Additional Notes

This is based heavily on context.Context to allow us to have proper
composite timeouts / cancellations. This is the recommended way to do
that in go which is also already used in other parts of the agent.

This commit also changes the following things:
- Ads a DestinationContext that is restartable and allows to "unclog" the destinations when necessary
- Destination starts using context.Context in order to have proper cancelation timeouts.
- Add some cleanups in a few `Stop()` functions to make unit testing easier
- Add `agent_test.go`, `sender_test.go` and `connection_manager_test.go` with basic tests (with working and non-working backends)
- Add `logs_config.stop_grace_period`, both because this has an effect on the logs that could be lost on restart (for tcp/udp) and because it makes unit testing easier.


* logs/input: fix data race in tailer

Also fixes a similar race with shouldStop (that hasn't been triggered yet)

Handle containerd logs (#2355) ### What does this PR do?

It Parses containerd logs to strip the header.

### Motivation

Containerd generate log files with a header 

```
2018-09-20T11:54:11.753589172Z stdout F {"a":"b","c":"d"}
```

In that case, we are able to remap the message in pipeline but we can't automatically parse JSON. We have to strip the header in order to enable automatic log parsing

Plug log agent kubernetes integration to autodiscovery (#2327) ### What does this PR do?

- Don't send sources and services to channels if there are no consumers instead of always consuming.
- Cleaned launchers.
- Added unit-tests
- Refactor the logic of k8 integration in log agent to use autodiscovery

### Motivation

Today, the logs-scheduler can be blocking and freeze the autodiscovery if a new config is scheduled and no component consumes it.
Unify the logic in the log agent to only use AD and remove pod watchers

### Additional Notes

This PR is a rebase of #2326 on top of #2324

Allow omitting GCE metadata from host tags Similar logic already exists for EC2: When collect_ec2_tags is set to
false, no extra tags are generated based on EC2 metadata. This unifies
the behavior so that GCE tags can also be excluded (though default
value for the new setting is different from the existing EC2 setting to
avoid changing existing behavior).

Motivation for the change is that GCE metadata may contain confidential
information (as it does in our case) and that must not be sent outside
the execution environment.

This also allows making the agent work like it did with version 5: With
version 5, if metadata collection was off but custom host tags were
specified, the tags got associated with the metrics. With version 6 the
tags are only ever sent when metadata collection is enabled, which also
sends the undesired GCE tags.

Purge error set by GetAttrString if a check doesn't have a __version__ (#2088) GetAttrString will set an error in the Python interpreter when a check
doesn't have a "__version__" attribute. If not purge/retrieve the error
will be pulled when importing the next python check.

[packaging] Avoid install failure if enabling systemd service fails (#1905) When `systemctl enable datadog-agent` fails, the package install
currently fails. 

The root cause on the dev env where we experienced the issue is
the following: our test for systemd, `command -v systemctl`,
tests for the presence of the `systemctl` command but not that systemd
is used as the init system on the current system. This can happen
for example on Ubuntu 14.04 (-> upstart) when the systemd deb has
been installed but systemd is not used as the init system. When that's the
case, `systemctl enable` fails.

Unfortunately it seems very hard to reliably determine what the current
init system is across all distros (even the cmdline of PID 1 isn't
always enough). The real fix would be to ship a different package for
every distro/version tuple, with pkg scripts tailored for that
distro/version.

So for now, let's just ignore these errors. Worst case scenario, on the
few systems where both commands exist, the agent install may not
stop/restart the agent service properly.

[packaging][linux] Create dd-agent user without a login shell (#1800) i.e. set `nologin` as the login shell of the `dd-agent` user when
creating it. This follows most distros' recommendations when creating
system users such as `dd-agent`.

If the `dd-agent` user already exists, do not change its login shell to
allow users to change it if they want and persist that across upgrades.

The path to `nologin` is different between RHEL/SUSE and debian/ubuntu,
account for that.

Fix panics from Viper lib when using proxy The 'Unmarshal' method from viper is no longer thread safe (since viper
autoupdate his internal map to be case insensitive). This may cause the
agent to panic when creating a HTTP transaction while another goroutine
read the configuration.

We now save the proxy settings when we first load the configuration.
This avoids calling 'Unmarshal' each time we create an HTTP transaction
and remove potential panics.

[metadata] Fix collection of host tags from GCP project & attributes (#1702) * Fix collection of project GCP host tags

The `project` and `numeric_project_id` tags weren't collected because
they weren't pulled from the correct key of the JSON response. This was
a regression from Agent 5.
We actually need to fetch the whole metadata JSON instead of just
the `instance` key to have access to the project metadata.
Fixes this, and updates the test fixture to reflect what the API
actually returns.

* Add collection of GCP instance attributes as host tags

Not collecting these was a regression from Agent5.
Use the same exclusion list as for Agent5.

* Add release note

"nice enough" for the backend.

[packaging] Remove executable permission from service def files (#1647) Whether the init system is systemd, upstart, or macOS' launchd, they
expect service def files not to have the executable bit.

Also, on recent systemd versions, having the exec bit on the service
files causes a warning. Let's remove it and normalize.

Fix race condition when stopping a worker When stopping a worker we might close the requeue channel while a worker
goroutine is trying to push a transaction to it. We need to wait for
every worker to actually stop before closing every channel from a
domain_forwarder.

Splitting the forwarder to have one per domain. The forwarder class has been split in two: forwarder and
domainForwarder.

We now spawn one "domainForwarder" per domain in the configuration. This
avoids slowing down one domain when another one is down.

We also split the health report for the forwarder to its own class to
ease testing.

Test coverage has been pushed from 79.4% to 92.4% and the README has been
updated.

Fix handling of empty fields in `resources` and `host` metadata payloads (#1286) * [resources] Remove the 'resources' key from the payload if it's empty

As crazy as it sounds, sobotka can crash if the 'resources' key is
present in the payload but is empty/isn't fully populated.

Let's just make sure we don't have the key in the payload if there's
no data in it.

* [resources] Only enable resources collector on Linux

To reflect A5 more closely, where sending resources regularly is
only done on Linux by default (on gohai's side it's not implemented
on Windows and can cause some CPU spikes on macOS).

* [host metadata] Omit empty `host-tags` entries in JSON payload

The backend expects an array under every key in `host-tags`. Let's just
omit any empty entry when JSON-serializing.

Make sure we the collector won't block if the user set only 1 runner In case the number of runners is lower than the long running check the
collector will block (no worker will be available). We now start a new
worker for each long running check. This allows the agent to run with
only one worker for recurrent checks.

[install_script][centos] Fix failures on repo/package install (#1145) * [install_script] Use a unique repo name on RHEL/CentOS and SUSE

The repo name needs to be unique on RHEL/CentOS, otherwise the user gets
this error: `Repository datadog is listed more than once in the
configuration`, and inconsistent behavior.

If the user is upgrading from Agent 5, the `[datadog]` name is used by
the stable repo, so use `[datadog-beta]` instead (it's reflected in the
file name too).

Do the same thing on SUSE (not sure it's required there, but it makes
sense anyway).

Update docs too.

* Remove `yum check-update` from install script

This command should be used to checked if updates of existing packages
are available, and fails if updates are indeed available, which makes
the whole script fail.

That's not the behavior we want. Let's remove it. `yum install` will
download the missing or expired metadata of all repos.

Fix dogstatsd unix socket rights By default a unix socket is created to be read by everybody but only
read by the owner. This defeat the purpose of a unix socket for
dogstatsd. This commit set write access to the socket for every user and
read access only for the owner (dd-agent).

Make sure we don't block the aggregator from the forwarder If the input queue in the forwarder is full, we don't want to block the
aggregator. This could only happen if we receive more new transaction
that the worker can try.

automatically).

Fix agent version (#1005) It was being overriden by `clusterAgentVersionDefault`.

[jmx] Remove conf fields from instance struct (#976) These fields aren't used anywhere and can cause type mismatches between
what's in the conf instances and the types defined in the struct
fields, even when downstream JMXFetch can accommodate different types
for some fields. (These mismatches make the jmx check throw errors)

If we want to introduce more agent-side validation of the jmx configs
we should do it directly in JMXFetch (and it already does a bit).

[cpu] Fix `system.cpu.stolen` metric (#988) Would previously always send `0`.

gopsutil has 2 fields in its `TimesStat` struct: `Stolen` and `Steal`.
Only `Steal` is actually populated with the "cpu stolen" value from
/proc/stat, `Stolen` is always left to the zero value.

This makes the check use `Steal` instead.

Resolve symlinks to executable consistently across platforms On macOS `os.Executable()` and `osext.ExecutableFolder()` don't resolve
symlinks to the executable (so for instance, when running
`datadog-agent` from the PATH, the resolved folder would be the
directory in the PATH instead of `/opt/datadog-agent/[...]`).

This makes things consistent across platforms by always trying to
resolve symlinks.

[Windows] implements apm agent (and lays groundwork for logs/process) (#820) Implements apm agent (and lays groundwork for log and process
agent) to be started as dependent services (rather than long-running
checks).

Removes the *.yaml.default files at build time, so the long running
checks won't be started (windows only)

Implements dependent service starting on Windows (stubbed out for
non-windows).

Installs apm & logs as manual start services, dependent upon the datadog
agent service.  This means that if the main agent stops, SCM will stop
the other two (if they're running).  If someone attempts to start one
(or both) of the other two and ddagent isn't running, SCM will
auto-start it.

[py] Fix return values in bindings when exceptions are raised (#870) * [subprocess_output] Fix exception raised on empty output 

Without this fix, `_util.get_subprocess_output` wouldn't raise an exception
on empty output, and would instead return `None` (which would then raise
a `TypeError` since we try to use `None` as a tuple).

Fix that.

In general, we *need* to return NULL to the python interpreter if an exception
has been set. Otherwise the exception is not raised properly in python
land and we're in uncharted undefined behavior land.

Also:
* fix typo for the string cmd logic
* fix return values in other py bindings when exceptions are set
* Add logging in get_subprocess_output function

[packaging] Fix upstart job definition for RHEL 6 (#808) `console log` is not supported by the version of upstart that RHEL 6
provides. Instead, we have to redirect the process' output to a file
and manually rotate it in a pre-start script.

This also divides the upstart jobs into 2 (one for the deb package, the
other for the rpm package): it makes more sense given the large
differences in features between the RHEL 6 upstart and the recent
Debian/Ubuntu upstart, and to keep the Deb/Ubuntu one as simple as
possible.

CI caching and pre-compilation (#778) CircleCI
- add a --precompile-only option to agent.build that precompiles the agent's dependencies in $GOPATH/pkg/ to speed up test compilation. Add that folder to the govendordeps cache
- change the cache key to v2-godeps-{{ .Branch }}-{{ .Revision }}. If not found, will lookup the latest cache for that branch with v2-godeps-{{ .Branch }}-, and latest from master if first build of the branch. As cache entries are immutable, the previous stategy got us pinned to the first inv deps after moving to CCI2
- enable race detection on integration-tests too, as they are faster with race+cache than before, and cache is only reused if all build flags are the same
- unify inv invocations in the CCI workflow
- [BUGFIX] make tests fail on gofmt

Appveyor
- remove cover for speedup (15 to 9 minutes)
- backport pre-compile logic (9 to 8 minutes, speedup is mostly erased by slow cache)

Log 'panic' when using upstart We don't have a way to alway log panics from the agent itself. So with
upstart we need to activate the 'log' option for the console. This way
panic logs will end up in /var/log/upstart/datadog-agent.log

By default systemd will redirect stderr to the journal, so we don't have
to specify anything.

[long-running checks] Fix check retries & fix races on `stop` (#736) Use a different approach to long-running check retries.

Before:
* Long running checks would always be retried when they returned an
  error. This meant that if a check was stopped and returned a non-zero
  exit code, it would also be retried. For some reason JMXFetch sometimes
  returns a non-zero exit code when killed, so we would end up with
  orphaned JMXFetch processes.
* some panics could arise because the Kill signal was sent even when
  the process had already exited
* retries would fail on apm, logs-agent & process-agent because the
  `Cmd` struct needs to be re-instantiated before `Start` is called
  again on it
* the runner would stop running checks one by one sequentially

After:

* The runner doesn't handle check retries. The long-running checks call
  the retries from their `Run` method, which allows them to handle stop
  requests more gracefully. Retries are attempted only on a certain
  type of error (`check.RetryableError`). Right now, this type of error
  is used only when the child process returns a non-zero exit code
* Long-running checks have a synchronisation logic that prevents them
  from restarting when a stop was requested, solving the orphaned
  processes issue and the race conditions
* retries now work on all long-running checks
* When stopping the runner, stop checks concurrently and use a global
  timeout

There's quite some code duplication between long-running checks. I'm
leaving the code duplication there since we have plans to move to a
different way of running the external agents (i.e. all long-running
checks except JMXFetch).

[log] Nicer log format for omnibus-built agent (#640) Currently the omnibus-built agent logs entries with this format:

```
2017-09-27 16:54:03 UTC | INFO | (/builds/datadog/datadog-agent/.omnibus/src/datadog-agent/src/github.com/DataDog/datadog-agent/pkg/collector/runner/runner.go:208) | Done running check load
```

which is ugly.

For now let's use a different format (remove path to go file):

```
2017-09-27 16:54:03 UTC | INFO | (runner.go:208 in work) | Done running check load
```

which gives a bit less info but is still good enough.

[py] Remove `dist/checks` directory from python path (#569) * [py] Remove `dist/checks` directory from python path

`dist/` is already in the python path, so all the modules in
`dist/checks` can and should be imported with
`import checks.my_module` instead of `import my_module`.

From what I've checked the agent6 core py code already accounts for
the `checks.` prefix when it loads the AgentCheck class for example,
so everything should still work.

* remove unused import

* [py] Add the `dist/checks.d` directory instead

Having `dist/checks.d` in the python path reflects well the path
structure of an installed agent and still allows devs to easily load
their custom checks in the development environment.

[py] Cast metric values to floats (#544) The python bindings can already handle casting `int`,
`decimal.Decimal`, etc, to floats, but some other types currently
throw exceptions, for example `string`s (and yes, some checks
do send numeric values as strings).

To address this, explicitly cast values to floats in the `AgentCheck`
class. This will still (rightfully) raise exceptions when the value
is not castable to a float, but it should make the behavior of
Agent6 closer to Agent5's.

[aggregator] Improve performance of context key generation (#439) Allocate a buffer with the right size once.

On a typical benchmark with many samples sent per second on the same
contexts, this function would take 50% of the total time needed by
`BufferedAggregator.AddSample()`.

This change typically divides the execution time of the function by a
factor of 3, and improves `AddSample` performance by ~30%.

resolves a data race in autoconfig (#414) Logging does not happen inline, it is handed off to a background thread. This is fine, as long as you only pass it objects that are threadsafe. This object is not, we have to use the mutex to ensure safety. Unfortunately, that means that when the log hands it off to another thread to log the line, it creates a data race. Formatting it inline will ensure that the object is not unsafely handed off to another thread.

[collector/loader] Fix nil dereference when a loader fails initializing (#401) Since each loader (as returned by LoaderCatalog()) is an interface,
it's not nil when the underlying concrete loader failed
initializing (and is actually nil). Once the loaders are added to
AutoConfig, we assume they're not nil, which leads to nil dereferences.

To fix this, make the factory functions return an error when a loader
initialization fails, and skip those loaders.

Move serialization to metrics and let the serializer route payload to the forwarder The serialization has been moved to the metrics so their internal logic it
kept there.

The serializer has been improved to handle the routing of metrics to the
forwarder. Different parts of the agent don't have to be aware of which
endpoint or format to use. This will allow us a dynamic routing (which
format/endpoint per metric type) and simplify the flow of metrics
through the agent.
normalize the checknames (#402)

[forwarder] Drop transaction when reponse is 404 (#399) Like the 400 and 413 http codes, 404 means that the backend is healthy
but the request is invalid. It makes sense to drop the transaction in
that case.

Useful in particular for endpoints that are not implemented on all the
accounts/environments, and agents with multiple domains/keys
configured. Dropping the 404 transactions allows not filling up the
retry queue with these transactions.

[py] Initialize site, and use PYTHONHOME (#390) * [py] Initialize site, and use PYTHONHOME

* Allow python to automatically initialize `site` when we initialize
the interpreter (see https://docs.python.org/2/library/site.html).
This makes python build its own default `PYTHONPATH` from the
`PYTHONHOME`, so that it can load modules (built-ins, `site-packages`
modules, etc).
* Instead of setting `PYTHONPATH` (since we let python build that on
its own), set `PYTHONHOME`. That'll pick up the embedded python, the
rest will be handled by python.

* [py] Log paths that we add to the python path

Use `exec` in script that starts the agent (#389) Using `exec` makes the agent process replace the shell script's
process instead of starting the agent process as a child process.

This is desirable for init systems that can't really track the actual
agent PID otherwise, and can then fail to track the agent process
properly.

[aggregator] Use `device` field for v1 metric endpoints (#326) Unfortunately the v1 metric endpoint does not currently handle a
`device:` tag in the same way as the `device` field. To avoid a
breaking change on this during an upgrade from agent5 to 6, use the
`device` field for the v1 metric endpoint.

Given that the v2 endpoint should handle `device:` tags correctly,
I use a quick fix and populate the `device` field right before
the serialization for the v1 endpoint. I left the serialization
itself untouched as it's quite error-prone.

[aggregator] Add `source_type_name` to metric series (#325) This field is important for backwards-compatibility on the backend:
different `source_type_name`s lead to different contexts.

By default all metrics posted to the metrics API get assigned the
`API` source type name, but metrics coming from the agent's collector
have always had the `System` source type name.

In order to use the same contexts as the agent5, we need to set this
source type name on all metrics coming from the collector.

This is unlikely to change in the backend in the near future, so we
add the field to both v1 and v2 payloads.

[py] Support yet another `AgentCheck.__init__` pattern (#298) This time when `instances` is the only argument passed in `kwargs`.

This pattern is quite common in the existing checks (since it's the
signature of the agent5's `AgentCheck.__init__`), so it makes sense
to support it.

Added a test case, and assertions in the python test code.

[snmp] further bugfixes (#304) * [snmp] instance should be snmp_device, submit counters as rates.

* [snmp] fix broken snmp tests.

[py] Add `increment`/`decrement` methods to `AgentCheck` (#297) * [py] Add `increment`/`decrement` methods to `AgentCheck`

Eases the transition from agent 5 to agent 6 for the checks. The
methods use `count` after adding a suffix to the metric name.

The suffix is required because `count` submits metrics with the
`COUNT` api metric type, whereas in agent 5 these methods use the
`RATE` api metric type, so we need to use a different metric name
(the backend doesn't support using a different API metric type for
the same metric name).

* [py] Log deprecation warning on first usage of `increment`/`decrement`

Logged at most once per check to avoid spamming the logs.

[py] Improve handling of py interpreter errors (#290) * Fix error handling by using the same `stickyLock` when fetching the
interpreter error

Changing locks between a python call that sets the error indicator
on the interpreter and a fetch of that error can result in the
error indicator not being there anymore when the fetch is attempted.

I'm not sure exactly why this happens. The fact that it happens
"randomly" makes me think that it's related to how the goroutines are
scheduled on OS threads by the go runtime, and to how this can affect
the state of the python interpreter.

* Various improvements on `getPythonError`:
  * now a method of the `stickyLock` struct for clarity
  * check that an error occurred before trying to fetch it (improves
  quality of error that's returned by the function)
  * normalize the python error (recommended by the python C API docs)
  * use the string representation of `pvalue` (improves error message)


* Use `getPythonError` in py's `check.Run` to fetch errors from the
python interpreter. We should use it wherever possible.

[metadata] Use slimmer k8s library for metadata. Based on feedback in https://github.com/DataDog/datadog-agent/pull/285
we can use a smaller library that pulls in significantly fewer
dependencies. The only trade-off is that we need to use getters in
function calls to avoid pointers everywhere because this is using older
style protobuf generated code.

Make text for cfgpath flag clearer  (#289) If you set the path in the following manner: ./bin/agent/agent start -f $(pwd)/datadog.yaml, it will use the one in ./bin/agent/dist/. This is because viper does not see a path and think, that's where the file is. It sees a path and thinks, that is a directory the file must be in. (See the logic https://github.com/spf13/viper/blob/0967fc9aceab2ce9da34061253ac10fb99bba5b2/viper.go#L1533-L1559.)

This updates the text to make it more clear that it should be directed at the directory the config resides in, rather than at the config file itself.

(We could also do some logic to add the parent path rather than the file itself, however I think this will result in less misunderstanding, as it has to be named datadog.yaml.)

[kubernetes] Add metadata provider Based on the data we are currently collecting in the `kubeutil` module
in `dd-agent`, this returns a payload format that lists all active
deployments, replica sets, services, pods and containers.

All data types can be "joined" via IDs in each model so we can resolve a
single container id with all the relevant metadata or treat each bit
independently for visualization, etc.

The goal would be to have this run on a subset of Agents which would
target the master and send this metadata to our systems for backend
resolution.

(un)marshaling into that format.

[py/loader] Unlock stickyLock before calling check.Configure (#266) `check.Configure` uses its own stickyLock (as the convention of the
exported method indicates), so we must unlock our lock before calling
it.

To make sure we always unlock locks, let's lock and unlock a new
stickyLock every time we need it to be on the safe side.

[agent build] Set `RPATH` with `-r` ldflag in rake build task (#256) And remove the custom `LD_RUN_PATH` from the environment when the agent
is built with omnibus.

This allows creating the same `agent.bin` binary whether the agent is
build with omnibus or with the `agent:build` rake task without omnibus.

Without this change, building an agent locally with `agent:build`
would create a binary without the `RPATH` set to the embedded lib dir,
so it wouldn't find the libraries located there. This would in turn
make the embedded python interpreter unable to find some libraries.


Also, exit if `go build` is unsuccessful.

[py] Log complete python errors + tracebacks when check import fails (#259) * [py] Log complete python errors + tracebacks when check import fails

In some cases the python module of a check can't be imported because
of a python code issue, in that case logging the traceback is useful.

Use a common function that retrieves and formats the python
interpreter error, and clears the error flag in the interpreter.
Any python c api call that returns an error should be followed by
a call of that common function to get a formatted string of the error.

* [py] Don't use a nested StickyLock

Using a nested lock unlocks to goroutine to the thread when the child
lock is unlocked (whereas we'd want that to happen when the parent lock
is unlocked).

Until we can figure out a good way to deal with this situation, don't
use nested locks, and add a warning to `getPythonError`.

[py] Improve error handling in bindings (#219) * Improve error handling in aggregator submission bindings:
  We try to handle all easily recoverable/ignorable errors in the
  bindings directly (usually by logging the issue and continuing the
  submission). The other errors are bubbled up to the python interpreter
  which will then raise an exception.
  All python C API calls have their errors handled or a comment
  explaining why we can abstain from checking errors.

* Log as much info as possible on check instance loading error:
  Log the whole traceback if there's one. If there's none log the pvalue.
  As a last resort try just logging the ptype.

[python] Add bindings to submit events from py checks (#207) The go code is written to be safe, but some edge cases may still not be
handled properly.

The approach to convert the python dict to a go Event struct is not
generic at all but I didn't find a strong reason to make it generic.
There is also some (limited) duplicated logic with some of `go-python`'s
internal api.

We encode unicode objects to python strings with `utf-8` encoding so
that go can handle them easily downstream. Catch and log any error.
The implicit assumption here is also that any python string is encoded
with `utf-8`.

Also, we bubble up errors correctly when passed `tags` is not a
sequence. This is one way of dealing with a CPython call returning an error.
Another way would be to clear the error from the python interpreter with
`PyErr_Clear()` and handle it entirely from the go/C code.

[aggregator] Add support for events submission from checks (part 1) (#191) Overall, events are handled in a similar way as service checks.

The whole event struct has to be submitted from the agent checks, this
allows handling all the optional fields of the event struct more
nicely (specifying them all as parameters of an `Sender.Event` function
wouldn't be very handy from checks).

The "Agent startup" event is slightly tricky to handle so it's not
taken care of here.

The events are sent to the agent 5 intake endpoint (see comments for
explanation).

For now:
- Haven't added the python bindings for py checks yet
- It only supports the v1 api endpoint (some work is queued to support
the v2 endpoint)

[aggregator] Add support for service checks from checks (part 1) (#171) The aggregator sends a `datadog.agent.up` service check by default
(like what the Agent5 collector does).

No aggregation is made on the service checks, so they're stored
directly in the BufferedAggregator.

The serialization and "forwarder forwarding" are made in separate
goroutines

For now:
* Haven't added the python bindings for py checks yet
* It only supports the v1 api endpoint (I'll queue some work to support
the v2 endpoint)

Also:
* renamed `submit_data` to `submit_metric` in preparation for
the py bindings.
* renamed check-metric-related types and variables so that there's
a clear distinction between what's made for metrics and what's made
for service checks

[aggregator] Avoid divisions by zero (#153) Would make the serialization fail downstream.

* In Rate metric when the 2 samples have the same timestamp
* When a sample is added to the aggregator with +/-Inf values
(which is usually the result of a division by zero in the code that
added the sample)

Also, avoid logging when no series are generated by a metric flush.
It can get really spammy otherwise, and doesn't provide any useful
information.

Avoid sharing internal states between multiple instances of a check. When a check had multiple instances 'newCheck := c' would not create a
new instance of the underlying struct of the interface. This means that
we end up with multiple reference to the same struct and the
informations of the last instance would apply to all. One the the side
effect would be that all check of a certain type would share the same
Sender (which makes Rates failed).

To avoid that we now register a factory function that allow us to
instantiate a new struct of the check type.

Check internal value of python errors to avoid crashing on a nil pointer In some cases python.PyErr_Fetch return ref to PyObject containing a nil pointer. Since the internal pointer is not exposed we have to query the internal type to detect nullness (that or using reflect).

[aggregator] Dedicated aggregation logic for checks (#44) * [aggregator] Use a different aggregation logic for checks

We stop using buckets for check metrics since it doesn't really make
sense to compute metrics like rates.

Use a new CheckSampler: there would be one CheckSampler for the python
checks (since they run sequentially) and one CheckSampler per go check
(since they could run concurrently).

Also implement Rate metrics to validate the design.

This still needs some polish: some abstractions of CheckSampler are
still close to the dogstatsd Sampler, and in some cases it doesn't
really make sense.

[dogstatsd][aggregator] First pass Simple prototype of a Dogstatsd server and an aggregator:

* both support only gauges for now
* the aggregator sends payloads to the metrics API endpoint of a local
forwarder (not implemented, so use a running dd-agent to forward the
packets)
* the aggregator has been plugged to the existing check runner
* each check has to specify its run interval to the aggregator
* most of the tests from dd-agent's dogstatsd have been copied (most of
them are not implemented yet) to give us an idea of the cases we need
to support
